title: Monday, 15th February, 2016

Here's there "for disposal" pool, in exhaustive chart form.

11:13 am
BE

BE

BE

11:14 am
BE

So, basically ....

BE

Through screening Anglo’s 49 assets on 2016 FCF using DBe and
spot, we derive a core portfolio of 21 assets which generates US$2.6bn of
2016e EBITDA and US$900m of cash flow after sustaining capex.

BE

Anglo wants a portfolio of first quartile assets which ‘deliver FCF through the
cycle’. We think there are two main screening methods which it is using to
determine its new core portfolio: each asset’s FCF position today and each
future cost curve position. In our view, one of the driving forces behind Anglo’s
determination of future cost curve positions is if the mine is mechanised. Nonmechanised mines have much higher numbers of employees than mechanised
underground and open-pit truck and shovel operations – and therefore carry
higher safety, health and labour relations risks, are less productive, more time
consuming for management and overall higher cost.
Focus on copper, platinum, diamonds; bulks (coal and iron ore) are out
Anglo’s initial screening is that it will focus on copper, platinum and diamonds.
It will seek to keep ‘only low cost’ operations in coal and be a ‘niche market
player’ in iron ore – in reality, we think that Anglo will exit bulks for the right
price. Overall, Anglo starts 2016 with 49 assets and we estimate 10 are
burning a total of US$1bn cash after capex this year at spot. Five are
Australian coal mines, one of which is Grosvenor due to the final portion of
project capital, and the remainder is for sale, or with a sale already agreed in
the case of Callide. Minas Rio iron ore is also burning cash, thus the decision
to exit bulks makes sense. Copper is marginally FCF negative, but we think will
be kept. The current low Rand has turned Kumba and platinum FCF positive.
Mechanisation: if Amandelbult cannot be mechanised, it should be sold
Of Anglo’s 49 operations, only four are not mechanised. All are platinum mine
complexes in South Africa: Amandelbult, Bokoni, Union and Rustenburg, and
all but Amandelbult have been earmarked for sale or are in the process of
being sold. Therefore, Amandelbult represents the largest remaining
conventional mining operation in the group, and thus carries the higher risks
we mention above. At present, Anglo is looking into the viability of mechanised
sections at Amandelbult – if this fails, we think an exit makes sense.

Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 6,340, up 374 (+6.27%), High: 6,364, Low: 6,207, Volume: 776.21k
11:21 am
BE

2015 beats. 2016 guidance looks cautious but only against the higher base.

BE

Deutsche Bank's quite impressed.

BE

RB’s FY15 results have ended being one of its best ever on record. Posting an
impressive 6% LFL growth combined to 210bp of margin expansion in FY15.
This at a time of generally below trend growth and margin performance across
global staples. Shorter term, Q4% LFL growth increased a stunning 7%
(Consensus 4.4%), whilst H2 margins increased 250bp (Consensus 80bp).
Meaning FY EBIT came in 5% ahead of expectations at £2374m and EPS 7%
ahead of expectations at 258.6p. We do note however that the EPS benefited
from a none recurrent tax benefit. We thus see the Q4 sales beat and the 5%
FY EBIT beat as the key good news items today.

11:22 am
BE

The initial details of the results yet again highlight how RB's strategic move
into consumer health is significantly enhancing its growth. Consumer Health
grew 14% LFL in both Q4 and for the FY. This also shows up through FY
Developed Market growth of 5% and Developing Market growth of 9%.
Interestingly and as seen elsewhere in the peer group, EMs accelerated further
in Q4 to 12% LFL after 8% LFL in the first nine months of the year. Although
gross margin expansion of 1 40bp and cost leverage contributed the vast
majority of the 210bp operating margin expansion, a notional 20bp drop in
Brand Equity Investment also contributed to the margin increase. Directionally
not what we look for, but somewhat of irrelevance in the context of such a
large revenue beat.

BE

Not stopping here
The outlook statement is robust. Despite the much higher growth and margin
outcome of FY15, for FY16, RB is targeting 4-5% LFL growth and another year
of moderate margin increase on top of which will come part of the ongoing
Supercharge savings. The combination of which should lead to another year of
healthy earnings growth. We also note that the cash flow performance has
been strong with c.100% of net income converted into cash. With this RB has
been able to increase the final dividend by 12% and will also allow the rolling
buyback to continue. Both of which will further enhance shareholder returns.

BE

As we type this short initial reaction to the results, RB shares are trading up
c.5% and some may feel they have missed the boat. However the key here is
that RB’s ongoing superior performance is largely self made – exemplary
operational execution in addition to the brilliance of the move into consumer
health. Neither benefits will stop soon and the compounded returns will simply
continue to come through to its shareholders. BUY

11:24 am
BE

BE

BE

Here's Barclays.

11:26 am
BE

Cost tailwinds and self help to perpetuate a now firmly best-in-class model. FY EBIT
came c4% above our expectations, driven by the early delivery of savings initiatives
and a strong contribution from mix. Such performance validates the choice to
prioritise Consumer Health over “traditional” home care segments, but 2016 will face
tougher comps as we believe OTC sales will face some channel de-stocking in H1
and as the contribution from Supercharge will be lower. We see gross margin
management as the key driver in 2016: the capacity to retain some of the benefits
from oil deflation will be made easier by barriers to entry present in OTC and EM
Hygiene, but in the longer run we see mix management as the main driver given how
optimal the cost base (and overall organization) has become

BE

Q4 growth supported by OTC, but mean reversion inevitable at some stage: Q4 sales
were up 7% lfl, driven by OTC sales up 14% lfl, where the performance was inflated by
some stocking in both US and Europe, which may unwind in H1 16. Company flagged
again that double-digit growth in OTC is unsustainable and that category growth
revolves around 4-6%. We expect the division to gradually return to a normalized runrate of 6-8% pa, translating into a group mid single digit organic sales growth.
Beyond 2016 gross margin tailwinds, margin expansion driven by category mix
management: We expect a 50bps margin expansion for FY16, supported by the
capacity to retain oil deflation benefits thanks to the barriers to entry in OTC and
Hygiene (less so in Home), and also helped by the “residual” contribution from
Supercharge (+30bps pa after +110bps in 2015). That said, given the diminishing
contribution from cost cutting, which is logical given how optimal the cost base has
become, we see mix management as the way to sustainably improve margins beyond
2016. This goes down to the prioritisation of OTC growth (which in our view generates
margins above 30%) vs Home & Hygiene, which may point at a decelerating pace of
margin expansion, but with strong visibility (at constant scope).
UW: We raise our 2016-17e EPS by 6% pa on higher sales and margin expectations,
coupled with less adverse FX assumptions and share buy-back contribution. Thus, we
raise our DCF-based TP to GBP59 (GBP57). Our DCF assumptions are unchanged

11:29 am
BE

I guess this all makes for a lot of committee meetings, which give the illusion of activity.

BE

(And hi, of course. Welcome to Monday. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily blah blah blah.)

BE

At 10pm last night, HSBC confirmed its (widely expected, but we believe regrettable) decision to remain domiciled in the UK, and thus ‘trapped’ in the European Union. In our view, the statement offers no quantified justification for the Board’s decision. Our existing forecasts remain unchanged as our base case made no allowance for the considerable financial benefits which may have accrued to HSBC’s shareholders had it decided to ‘escape’. Trading on

11:30 am
BE

Chairman Douglas Flint summarised the Board view by commenting that “the combination of our strategic focus on Asia and maintaining our hub in one of the world’s leading international financial centres, London, was not only compatible, but offered the best outcome for our customers and shareholders.”
Most obviously, HSBC will now, as expected, remain liable to a UK bank levy calculated on its global balance sheet until (at least) 2021. This charge is expected to peak at over $1.5bn in 2015, (see page 2), with no relief against UK Corporation Tax. As far as we can tell, consensus similarly assumed no early relief in relation to the UK bank levy. Looking ahead, we believe that the level of UK political risk attaching to periods after 2020 remains high.
We also see it as a matter of regret that HSBC will remain lead-regulated in the UK. We believe this de facto confers higher capital requirements relative to its international peers, although we acknowledge that the scale of incremental cost, including the burden of compliance with EU directives, is somewhat opaque, and, in any event, HSBC’s UK businesses could not have escaped the material adverse impact arising from the 2011 Vickers Report, to be implemented in the UK by 2019.
Overall, we see HSBC’s announcement as a missed opportunity. We regard (deferred) “concessions” granted by the Chancellor last year on the bank levy as inadequate, and see the burden of lead-regulation by the UK as a high price to pay for a bank seeking to compete effectively in international markets, especially Asia. On the other hand, we do acknowledge that uncertainty over the bank’s cost of equity may also have weighed on the Board’s decision.
Buy rec and (unchanged) 540p RoE-g/CoE-g-derived TP reaffirmed.

BE

And no other analyst has bothered to comment, it appears. Fair enough.

I'll come to the full "high and secure payers" list in a moment, but here's the preamble.

BE

The Bank of Japan's recent decision to move to negative interest rates has
weighed heavily on the risk appetite for equities and driven bond yields to new
lows. The current low bond yield environment is likely to provide further
incentive for investors to focus on dividend investing, particularly in areas of
the market where the yield is attractive and secure.

BE

The gap between equity and bond yields remains at record highs but
Europe's absolute dividend yield is only modestly above average.
Relative valuations for equities vs fixed income remain attractive with the gap
between dividend yields and bond / credit yields at or close to record highs.
However, on an absolute basis, Europe's dividend yield for both the market in
aggregate and the median stock is only modestly above its long-run average.
Further, only 26% of stocks in the market have a dividend yield of over 4%. At
a sector level, the only sectors that yield above the market dividend yield are
Energy, Financials, Utilities, Telecoms, Media and Materials

11:39 am
BE

Given that the market's dividend yield is not overly attractive and concentrated
in only a few sectors, we think it is important to overlay a qualitative approach
to identify the best dividend stock ideas. Hence we've updated our preferred
high & secure yield screen (MSSTDIVS), which lists stocks where MS analysts
forecast 2016e dividend yield of at least 4% and where they think there is a
very low probability of a dividend cut over the next two years

11:53 am
BE

Oh, hey, but thanks to Arash for flagging up a bit more DPL.

BE

London Central Portfolio Limited -- not sure who they are, but let's roll with it -- has been through the HMRC data on corporate owned property.

BE

The Headline Statistics:
HMRC Data shows that just 3,990 properties nationwide are currently owned in NNPs for owner-occupation.
63% are valued between £2m - £5m, 23% are valued between £5m - £10m, 14% are valued above £10m
The band for properties over £20m, which would most likely be aligned to so-called ‘oligarch mansions’, includes only 230 properties which equates to 0.001% of all properties in England and Wales.
In terms of value, total ATED tax receipts for 2015 totalled £116m to the benefit of the UK economy.
6.3% less properties are now owned by NNPs, compared with 2014.
The total number of properties bought over £10m recorded by Land Registry since the ATED tax was introduced in 2012 has increased 5 times from 13 to 65.

11:55 am
BE

Regional Breakdown
London as a whole accounted for 89% of ATED tax receipts (£103m)
The South East accounted for 10% (£11m)
The other 2% came from the rest of the UK (£2m)
Top Local Authorities
The City of Westminster accounted for 52% (£60m) of total ATED receipts in 2015
In second place was Kensington and Chelsea accounting for 27% (£32m)
The other 21% of ATED tax receipts have come from Barnet, Camden, Runnymede and ‘the rest of the UK’ (£24m).

BE

These official statistics demonstrate that numbers are less than 1/5 of previous estimates, such as those from Transparency International, which claimed that 36,342 properties in London were owned in off-shore vehicles alone. Whilst the official numbers will increase when the tax bands extend to lower value properties, this is unlikely to be significant as such properties are not usually bought in corporate wrappers.

Overall, it appears that the high levels of taxation for properties bought in corporate wrappers, is beginning to outweigh any tax planning benefits, with a 6% fall in the number recorded in 2015 compared with 2014. De-enveloping (dropping properties out of NNPs and into personal names) has begun to take place, in line with the Chancellor’s declared intentions.

This is corroborated by statistics from the Land Registry also analysed by LCP. This demonstrates that the number of properties over £10m in Central London, registering on the Land Registry, has increased 5 fold from 13 in 2011, before the tax disincentives were first announced, to 65 in 2015. Previously, many of these properties would have been acquired in corporate wrappers and hence not recorded at Land Registry.

BE

I've a suspicion this reflects quite a recent trend to move property out of holding companies.

11:57 am
BE

You can go through the Land Registry data quite easily for anywhere prime residential and see a lot of real names now, where it used to all be Cayman Islands and Guernsey.

BE

Speculation on the reasons why is always welcome.

BE

(@Icarus: yup, though without being too cryptic and conspiratorial, I guess there are incentives in the other direction too.)

11:58 am
undefined
BE

So, there was a request earlier for Yen-related stuff.

BE

And since we have one minute left, that's as good a way as any to fill it.

12:00 pm
BE

Deutsche.

BE

Markets crossed a threshold globally last week. In particular, US and European
high-risk bond markets slipped into a warning zone. The JPY appreciated as
risk-off activity deepened. Slower momentum by the US economy has become
apparent as well, and some observers even started speculating about a
possible recession. We think this development indicates that the USD/JPY is
losing its most important support of US economic steadiness. We had to
abandon our USD/JPY bull outlook in place since 2012 and are focusing on the
possibility of a 105-110 range over the next several months.
Abenomics is coming to very crucial stage yet ahead of the election slated for
July. The MoF might intervene in USD/JPY to secure a rate at around 110. We
also believe the BoJ may consider further easing measures depending on
circumstances. We see coordinated actions by major countries cannot be ruled
out. However, further JPY appreciation is a possibility if China devalues the
CNY by 10% or so, because of a resulting risk-off impact to not only
EMs/resources markets but also developed countries.

BE

The market might exhibit a reversal from the overreaction this week. Yet we
expect a fairly heavy upside ceiling for the USD/JPY at over-115 because of
rally-selling pressure from hedgers and many other market players. We think
market sentiment could easily weaken when it is confronted by adverse news
on China, stock prices, credit and crude oil when the US is unable to fulfill the
role of leading the global economy. We will be closely monitoring market
activity and policies in China after the Lunar New Year holidays this week.
The Japanese economy is sluggish too. Japan's 4Q 2015 GDP was announced
today. GDP fell by 1.4% QoQ annualized (vs. the -0.8% market forecast and
+0.3% in the previous quarter). The BoJ starts its negative interest rate policy
on 16 February, but we do not expect Japanese investors to begin strong
enough buying of foreign bonds to restore a JPY depreciation trend right away
due to the recent risk-off environment. We anticipate emphasis on unwinding
USD/JPY longs built during the 115-125 range, which has lasted for just over
the past year, to come first.

12:02 pm
BE
